newsitem.title: CHILE: Latam stocks seen rising but profit-taking looms.
newsitem.headline: Latam stocks seen rising but profit-taking looms.

text.p: Latin American stocks, which enjoyed a lively rally last week, are expected to resume their winning streak this week, although a wave of profit-taking could snap the string of gains, said traders.

"Friday's U.S. jobs data was a huge surprise and stretched the local rally, but stocks will soon have to pause and consolidate," said Dario Lizzano, at Buenos Aires brokerage Rio Valores in remarks which apply to most Latin American markets.

Although the bullish mood is region-wide, investors are focusing on domestic issues ranging from protests against labor reforms in Argentina to prospects of higher electricity prices in Venezuela, which are seen setting the Caracas bourse alight.

In Brazil, stocks are seen staging a moderate rally, with the bolsa watching for further developments in municipal elections and awaiting the release of September trade figures, said dealers. "The market will be eyeing political alliances for the second round of municipal elections," said Evandro dos Rios Jr, a trader at the Indusval brokerage house.
The bourse will also be dominated by a fight over options settlements to be made on October 21, they said.
Brazilian stocks ended last week up 2.6 percent at 66,269 points with volume thin at an average $350 million.
Argentine blue chips are expected to keep a firm underlying tone this week, although profit-taking could rob the market of momentum, said traders.
Players are seen continuing to focus on the government's labor reform initiatives in the face of mounting trade union protests.
So far new strike threats coming only days after a 36-hour walkout were not seen marring the government's drive to make employment conditions more flexible.

The selective MerVal index jumped four percent last week to a three month high of 580.03 points, drawing momentum from Wall Street and the successful launch of Argentina's $1 billion global bond issue.
In Caracas, stocks are seen bullish at the prospect of higher electricity tariffs, although investors could soon move to cash in gains, said dealers.
"Theoretically there should be a correction as all signs are of an overbought market," said a trader at brokerage Bancaracas.
But the week ended "on the up; there's still residual demand and we could see further rises," he added.
The 19-share index vaulted nearly 17 percent last week to close at 6,391.01 points.
The Mexican bolsa, which rallied over four percent last week, is seen looking to Wall Street and to company quarterly results for direction this week, said dealers.
As in other markets, the rally could falter on a wave of profit-taking, they said.
The Mexican bolsa closed Friday up 0.08 percent at 3,376.05 points with a rise in the week of 4.3 percent.
Chilean stocks, which rallied last week amid optimism local interest rates could soon fall, are seen resuming their upward slant this week, said traders.
"The market wasn't particularly overbought last week, so we expect it to be mixed to positive this week," said Lance Eckel, an analyst at brokerage Sud Americano.
The 40-share IPSa index ended the week up 2.09 percent at 101.01 points.
--Santiago newsroom, 562-699-5595x212
